talks.talk_title: Platform Engineering untold truths: is it just an infrastructure matter?
talks.description: The increasing complexity of software development presents significant risks and inefficiencies, especially for large enterprises. Thatâ€™s why companies require a structured approach to streamline software delivery, with a focus on platform engineering and internal developer platforms. While existing literature often discusses platform engineering in terms of DevOps tool integration and infrastructure provisioning, its scope extends far beyond these aspects. To truly enhance service scalability and quality, platforms must prioritize data encapsulation and composability. This means addressing not just the IT infrastructure, but the entire organizational framework. Infrastructure management represents only the tip of the iceberg; to drive a successful platform engineering initiative, factors like data management and composability are equally crucial. Letâ€™s delve into the unspoken truths of platform engineering by examining the fundamental principles necessary for a successful platform initiative.

talks.talk_title: An open-source first step to greenify your cloud environments
talks.description: In a context where the ICT sector alone produces around the 1.4% of global CO2 emissions, adopting mindful resource usage is of paramount importance. One of the most challenging aspects about green software is understanding where to start. Before delving into more complex things, a good starting point is to raise awareness of the hidden â€˜zombiesâ€™ within our infrastructure and then proceed to eliminate them. In this session, weâ€™ll explore what green software is, its environmental and economic implications and how kube-green (an open source project listed in the CNCF landscape) immediately help us make our cloud infrastructures more sustainable.

talks.talk_title: Practical policy-as-code with OPA and a managed sidecar container
talks.description: The cloud-native landscape brings incredible advantages, but it also introduces new security challenges, making safeguarding a top priority. In the traditional policy enforcement model, manual management leaves organizations vulnerable to inevitable breaches due to human error â€“ a matter of 'when,' not 'if.' Enter Policy-as-Code (PaC), a game-changing approach that leverages code to define and manage policies, transforming rules and conditions into actionable directives. By keeping policy definitions in source code control, whenever a change is made, it can be tested, validated, and then executed. The goal of PaC is not to detect policy violations but to prevent them. In this session we delve into the practical implementation of a Policy-as-Code strategy for your organization using RÃ¶nd and Open Policy Agent, two powerful open-source projects that could help you to redefine your security paradigm.
